HNF101.name: Personal Nutrition and Health
HNF101.description: Application of nutritional science to personal health and every-day life. Tools, strategies, and resources related to personal diet, nutrition, and wellness.

HNF102.name: Dietary Supplements: Evidence vs Hype
HNF102.description: Effects of dietary supplements such as vitamins, herbs, performance enhancers and functional foods on health and performance. Evaluation of supplement safety and effectiveness. Laws and policies relative to health claims.

HNF150.name: Introduction to Human Nutrition
HNF150.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF150.description: Nutrient function and metabolism. Food and nutrients in health and disease. Socioeconomic and environmental influences on food and health. Incorporation of healthy food choices into daily living.

HNF220.name: History of Food and Alcohol
HNF220.description: How food and alcohol have shaped world history. Relationship to politics, nationalism, religion, economics and culture. Consumption, trade, migration, slavery, globalization, environmental impacts.

HNF250.name: Contemporary Issues in Human Nutrition
HNF250.description: Current topics and controversies in nutrition, health, and chronic disease. Concepts of health. Credible sources of nutrition information and research. Governing agencies and policy. Ethical issues related to nutrition.
HNF250.prerequisite: (HNF 150) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
HNF250.restrictions: Open to students in the Nutritional Sciences Major or in the Lyman Briggs Nutritional Sciences Coordinate Major.

HNF250L.name: Professional Development and Career Planning in Nutrition
HNF250L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HNF250L.description: Experiential learning and career opportunities in nutrition. Skills for professional and career development.
HNF250L.restrictions: Open to students in the Nutritional Sciences Major and open to students in the Lyman Briggs Nutritional Sciences Coordinate Major.

HNF300.name: Experimental Approaches to Foods
HNF300.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HNF300.description: Effects of preparation methods and ingredient substitutions on chemical and physical properties of food constituents. Effects of changes in chemical and physical properties on functional and sensory attributes of foods.
HNF300.prerequisite: ((CEM 143 or concurrently) or (CEM 251 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
HNF300.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major or in the Food Science Major.

HNF310.name: Nutrition in Medicine for Pre-Health Professionals
HNF310.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF310.description: Relationship of nutrition and dietary practices to human health and treatment of clinical conditions. Health care team approach to nutrition issues.
HNF310.prerequisite: (HNF 150) and ((PSL 250 or concurrently) or (PSL 310 or concurrently) or (PSL 431 or concurrently))

HNF320.name: Professional Practice of Dietetics and Nutrition
HNF320.description: Scope of the profession of dietetics. Foundation knowledge and skills for dietetics. Food patterns for health and disease management.
HNF320.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major.

HNF350.name: Advanced Human Nutrition and Metabolism
HNF350.description: Nutrient function, metabolism, and interaction in humans at the molecular, cellular, tissue, organ and system level. Mechanistic relationships of nutritional status to health and disease.
HNF350.prerequisite: (HNF 250 or HNF 320) and (PSL 250 or PSL 310 or PSL 431) and (BMB 200 or BMB 401 or BMB 461)
HNF350.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major or in the Nutritional Sciences Major or in the Lyman Briggs Nutritional Sciences Coordinate Major.

HNF375.name: Community Nutrition
HNF375.description: Guidelines for dietary and anthropometric components of nutritional status, including health surveys. Agencies and programs that address food and nutritional needs of target populations throughout the life cycle.
HNF375.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors.

HNF377.name: Applied Community Nutrition
HNF377.description: Skill development in nutritional assessment including dietary, anthropometric, clinical, biochemical and ecological assessment.
HNF377.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major or in the Nutritional Sciences Major or in the Lyman Briggs Nutritional Sciences Coordinate Major.

HNF385.name: Public Health Nutrition
HNF385.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
HNF385.description: Nutrition from a public health perspective. Overview of public health research, evidence-based recommendations and epidemiology. Diet and nutrition assessment. Ethical issues surrounding public health nutrition recommendations.
HNF385.prerequisite: (HNF 150) and ((STT 200 or concurrently) or (STT 201 or concurrently) or (STT 224 or concurrently) or (STT 231 or concurrently) or (STT 421 or concurrently) or (STT 464 or concurrently) or approval of department)

HNF400.name: Art and Science of Food Preparation
HNF400.description: Art and science of food preparation in relation to cost, health, dietary modification, and historical, regional, ethnic, and religious customs. Product evaluation using sensory techniques. Offered half of semester.
HNF400.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Dietetics major.

HNF406.name: Global Foods and Culture
HNF406.description: Factors impacting food consumption from a human ecological perspective. International and national food consumption patterns. Geographic, political, and economic aspects of food consumption. Food availability and distribution. Family structure, taboos, religion, and food-related health problems.

HNF415.name: Global Nutrition
HNF415.description: Burdens, causes, and consequences of undernutrition globally. Interaction of nutrition with illness, obesity, and reproductive health. Approaches, policies, and programs to prevent undernutrition.

HNF440.name: Foodservice Operations
HNF440.description: Principles, processes and control strategies in foodservice operations. Menu planning, procurement, and on-premise storage and issuance. Purchasing, ethics, production, safety and sanitation.
HNF440.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major.

HNF444.name: The Business of Nutrition Services
HNF444.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HNF444.description: Human resources, budget and financial resources. Technology and marketing in food and nutrition services management. Utilizing prototype computer software for procurement, receiving, inventory management, recipe adjustment, nutrient analysis, budgets and accounting.
HNF444.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics major.

HNF445.name: Foodservice Management Practicum
HNF445.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HNF445.description: Receipt, storage, preparation and service of foods. Safety and sanitation. Design, layout, and care of equipment. Costing of food services. Students must purchase meal ticket. Offered half of semester.
HNF445.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Dietetics major and open to graduate students in the Human Nutrition major. Approval of department.

HNF450.name: Nutrition in the Prevention and Treatment of Disease
HNF450.description: Nutrition and its relationship to health and disease using a basic research approach.
HNF450.prerequisite: (HNF 250 and HNF 350) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

HNF453.name: Nutrition and Human Development
HNF453.description: Role of nutrients in anatomical, physiological, and biochemical processes as related to human growth and development. Nutrition throughout the life cycle. Nutritional assessment integrating the nutrition care process and age specific programs.
HNF453.prerequisite: (HNF 375 or HNF 377) and (PSL 250 or PSL 310 or PSL 431)
HNF453.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major or in the Nutritional Sciences Major or in the Lyman Briggs Nutritional Sciences Coordinate Major.

HNF457.name: Sports and Cardiovascular Nutrition
HNF457.description: Nutrition for optimizing sport training, recovery, and performance; power, intermittent, and endurance sports. Role of nutrition, physical activity and exercise on cardiovascular and overall health.
HNF457.prerequisite: (HNF 150) and (PSL 250 or PSL 310 or PSL 431) and (BMB 200 or BMB 401 or BMB 461 or KIN 310)

HNF471.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy I
HNF471.description: Anatomical, physiological and biochemical changes associated with diabetes, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular and bariatric conditions. Nutrition assessment, nutrition diagnoses, interventions, monitoring and evaluation, documentation and quality improvement as guided by Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics' Nutrition Care Process. Interactions of diet therapies with other therapies including pharmacologic and complementary and alternative medicine.
HNF471.prerequisite: (HNF 350) and ANTR 350 and (PSL 250 or PSL 310) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
HNF471.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major.

HNF472.name: Medical Nutrition Therapy II
HNF472.description: Anatomical, physiological and biochemical changes associated with hematologic, musculoskeletal, renal, respiratory, hepatobiliary, cancer, HIV/AIDS, metabolic stress and multiple organ failure. Nutrition assessment, nutrition diagnoses, interventions, monitoring and evaluation, documentation and quality improvement as guided by Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics' Nutrition Care Process. Interactions of diet therapies with other therapies including pharmacologic and complementary and alternative medicine.
HNF472.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Dietetics Major.

HNF475.name: International Studies in Human Nutrition
HNF475.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF475.description: Education abroad experience. Contemporary problems affecting food science and human nutrition in world, national and local communities.

HNF485.name: Advanced Public Health Nutrition
HNF485.description: Survey design, data collection and analysis of nutrition and health data. Use of statistical analysis software (SPSS/SAS). Interpretation and presentation of research results.
HNF485.restrictions: Open to students in the Nutritional Sciences Major and open to students in the Lyman Briggs Nutritional Sciences Coordinate Major.

HNF490.name: Independent Study
HNF490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF490.description: Individual study of selected topics in foods, foodservice management or nutrition.
HNF490.restrictions: Open to seniors. Approval of department.

HNF490H.name: Honors Independent Study
HNF490H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF490H.description: Individual study of selected topics in foods, foodservice management or nutrition.
HNF490H.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of department.

HNF491.name: Topics in Human Nutrition
HNF491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF491.description: Selected topics of current interest in human nutrition .

HNF494.name: Practicum
HNF494.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF494.description: Professional experience in selected settings and organizations under faculty supervision.
HNF494.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of Food Science and Human Nutrition. Approval of department.

HNF820.name: Advanced Biochemical Nutrition
HNF820.description: Biochemical aspects of advanced human nutrition

HNF821.name: Advanced Vitamins and Minerals
HNF821.description: The function of vitamins and minerals in human nutrition

HNF823.name: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
HNF823.description: Survey of research methods used in human nutrition.

HNF824.name: Nutrition Policies and Programs
HNF824.description: Overview of U.S. nutrition policies and programs, including case studies, development and methods of evaluation.

HNF825.name: Nutritional Immunology
HNF825.description: Role of nutritional status on immune function and infectious disease.

HNF826.name: Obesity and Chronic Disease
HNF826.description: Adipose biology and the role of obesity in chronic disease including diabetes, heart disease and cancer.

HNF840.name: Human Nutrition and Chronic Diseases
HNF840.description: Dietary intervention and treatment of chronic diseases

HNF843.name: Community Nutritional Assessment
HNF843.description: Nutritional assessment of population groups in community settings. Interpretation of national and international health data.

HNF890.name: Supervised Individual Study
HNF890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF890.description: Faculty supervised study of nutrition areas of individual interest.
HNF890.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Food Science and Human Nutrition. Students are limited to a combined total of 10 credits in HNF 890 and HNF 894.

HNF891.name: Topics in Human Nutrition
HNF891.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF891.description: Current topics in applied and basic human nutrition.

HNF892.name: Nutrition Seminar
HNF892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HNF892.description: Presentations by students on current topics in nutrition.

HNF894.name: Human Nutrition Practicum
HNF894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF894.description: Experience in agencies or offices related to Human Nutrition. Field experience required.
HNF894.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Food Science and Human Nutrition. Students are limited to a combined total of 10 credits in HNF 890 and HNF 894. Approval of department.

HNF898.name: Master's Project
HNF898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF898.description: Directed scholarly participation in support of Plan B master's degree requirements in human nutrition.
HNF898.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Human Nutrition major.

HNF899.name: Master's Thesis Research
HNF899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF899.restrictions: Open only to master's students in Human Nutrition and Foods.

HNF936.name: Protein Nutrition and Metabolism
HNF936.description: Nutritional and endocrine regulation of protein synthesis and degradation, protein quality assessment, protein status, and protein-energy malnutrition. Protein metabolism during exercise. Metabolism, digestion, and absorption of amino acids and proteins.

HNF999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
HNF999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HNF999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Human Nutrition major.
